xldoc.title: Foundations of Analytics
xldoc.keywords: x-logic xml logic philosophy analytic formal

section.title: Overview
section.abstract: Foundation systems for formal analysis play the same role as logical foundations for mathematics but are aimed at a broader range of applications.

sbcol.subsec: In our theory of knowledge we propose the factorisation of semantics into a formalisable abstract semantics and an informal concrete semantics

section.title: Higher Order Set Theory
section.abstract: Our preferred starting point is the formalisation of set theory in Higher Order Logic. This provides a universal semantic foundation for X-Logic, and a suitable framework for further formal foundational experiments.

section.title: Well-Founded Systems
section.abstract: Some experiments in foundation systems intended to deliver pragmatic features like polymorhphism and structured name-spaces without rocking the boat.

section.title: Reflexive Foundations
section.abstract: The identification of functions with well-founded graphs is both fruitful and cumbersome. Is it possible to reconcile this classical framework with a more liberal notion of "rule"?

section.title: Proof and Computation
section.abstract: Formal foundation systems are normally associated with fixed sets of rules and axioms. For X-Logic, liberalisation is proposed, yielding a closer relationship between proof and computation.

section.title: Where the Buck Stops
section.abstract: The attempt to define semantics formally leads either to infinite regress or to meta-circular semantics. We propose the latter.
